sn46.6:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sākete viharati añjanavane migadāye.
sn46.6:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāketa in the deer park at the Añjana Wood.

sn46.6:1.2.pli: Atha kho kuṇḍaliyo paribbājako yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn46.6:1.2.eng: Then the wanderer Kuṇḍaliya went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

sn46.6:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho kuṇḍaliyo paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn46.6:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:

sn46.6:1.4.eng: “Worthy Gotama, I like to hang around the monasteries and visit the assemblies.

sn46.6:1.5.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bho gotama, pacchābhattaṃ bhuttapātarāsassa ayamācāro hoti—
sn46.6:1.5.eng: When I’ve finished breakfast, it’s my habit to

sn46.6:1.6.pli: ārāmena ārāmaṃ uyyānena uyyānaṃ anucaṅkamāmi anuvicarāmi.
sn46.6:1.6.eng: wander from monastery to monastery, from park to park.

sn46.6:1.7.pli: So tattha passāmi eke samaṇabrāhmaṇe itivādappamokkhānisaṃsañceva kathaṃ kathente upārambhānisaṃsañca:
sn46.6:1.7.eng: There I see some ascetics and brahmins speaking for the sake of winning debates and finding fault.

sn46.6:1.8.eng: But what benefit does the worthy Gotama live for?”

sn46.6:1.9.eng: “The benefit the Realized One lives for, Kuṇḍaliya, is the fruit of knowledge and freedom.”

sn46.6:2.1.pli: “Katame pana, bho gotama, dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā vijjāvimuttiṃ paripūrentī”ti?
sn46.6:2.1.eng: “But what things must be developed and cultivated in order to fulfill knowledge and freedom?”

sn46.6:2.2.pli: “Satta kho, kuṇḍaliya, bojjhaṅgā bhāvitā bahulīkatā vijjāvimuttiṃ paripūrentī”ti.

sn46.6:2.3.pli: “Katame pana, bho gotama, dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā satta bojjhaṅge paripūrentī”ti?
sn46.6:2.3.eng: “But what things must be developed and cultivated in order to fulfill the seven awakening factors?”

sn46.6:2.4.pli: “Cattāro kho, kuṇḍaliya, satipaṭṭhānā bhāvitā bahulīkatā satta bojjhaṅge paripūrentī”ti.

sn46.6:2.5.pli: “Katame pana, bho gotama, dhammā bhāvitā, bahulīkatā cattāro satipaṭṭhāne paripūrentī”ti?
sn46.6:2.5.eng: “But what things must be developed and cultivated in order to fulfill the four kinds of mindfulness meditation?”

sn46.6:2.6.pli: “Tīṇi kho, kuṇḍaliya, sucaritāni bhāvitāni bahulīkatāni cattāro satipaṭṭhāne paripūrentī”ti.

sn46.6:2.7.pli: “Katame pana, bho gotama, dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā tīṇi sucaritāni paripūrentī”ti?
sn46.6:2.7.eng: “But what things must be developed and cultivated in order to fulfill the three kinds of good conduct?”

sn46.6:2.8.pli: “Indriyasaṃvaro kho, kuṇḍaliya, bhāvito bahulīkato tīṇi sucaritāni paripūretīti.

sn46.6:3.1.pli: Kathaṃ bhāvito ca, kuṇḍaliya, indriyasaṃvaro kathaṃ bahulīkato tīṇi sucaritāni paripūretīti?
sn46.6:3.1.eng: And Kuṇḍaliya, how is sense restraint developed and cultivated so as to fulfill the three kinds of good conduct?

sn46.6:3.2.pli: Idha, kuṇḍaliya, bhikkhu cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā manāpaṃ nābhijjhati nābhihaṃsati, na rāgaṃ janeti.
sn46.6:3.2.eng: A mendicant sees an agreeable sight with their eye. They don’t desire it or enjoy it, and they don’t give rise to greed.

sn46.6:3.3.pli: Tassa ṭhito ca kāyo hoti, ṭhitaṃ cittaṃ ajjhattaṃ susaṇṭhitaṃ suvimuttaṃ.
sn46.6:3.3.eng: Their mind and body are steady internally, well settled and well freed.

sn46.6:3.4.pli: Cakkhunā kho paneva rūpaṃ disvā amanāpaṃ na maṅku hoti appatiṭṭhitacitto adīnamānaso abyāpannacetaso.
sn46.6:3.4.eng: But if they see a disagreeable sight they’re not dismayed; their mind isn’t hardened, dejected, or full of ill will.

sn46.6:3.5.pli: Tassa ṭhito ca kāyo hoti ṭhitaṃ cittaṃ ajjhattaṃ susaṇṭhitaṃ suvimuttaṃ.
sn46.6:3.5.eng: Their mind and body are steady internally, well settled and well freed.

sn46.6:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, kuṇḍaliya, bhikkhu sotena saddaṃ sutvā …pe…
sn46.6:4.1.eng: Furthermore, a mendicant hears an agreeable sound with the ear …

sn46.6:4.2.eng: smells an agreeable odor with the nose …

sn46.6:4.3.eng: tastes an agreeable flavor with the tongue …

sn46.6:4.4.eng: feels an agreeable touch with the body …

sn46.6:4.5.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya manāpaṃ nābhijjhati nābhihaṃsati, na rāgaṃ janeti.
sn46.6:4.5.eng: knows an agreeable idea with their mind. They don’t desire it or enjoy it, and they don’t give rise to greed.

sn46.6:4.6.pli: Tassa ṭhito ca kāyo hoti, ṭhitaṃ cittaṃ ajjhattaṃ susaṇṭhitaṃ suvimuttaṃ.
sn46.6:4.6.eng: Their mind and body are steady internally, well settled and well freed.

sn46.6:4.7.pli: Manasā kho paneva dhammaṃ viññāya amanāpaṃ na maṅku hoti appatiṭṭhitacitto adīnamānaso abyāpannacetaso.
sn46.6:4.7.eng: But if they know a disagreeable idea they’re not dismayed; their mind isn’t hardened, dejected, or full of ill will.

sn46.6:4.8.pli: Tassa ṭhito ca kāyo hoti, ṭhitaṃ cittaṃ ajjhattaṃ susaṇṭhitaṃ suvimuttaṃ.
sn46.6:4.8.eng: Their mind and body are steady internally, well settled and well freed.

sn46.6:5.1.pli: Yato kho, kuṇḍaliya, bhikkhuno cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā manāpāmanāpesu rūpesu ṭhito ca kāyo hoti, ṭhitaṃ cittaṃ ajjhattaṃ susaṇṭhitaṃ suvimuttaṃ.
sn46.6:5.1.eng: When a mendicant’s mind and body are steady internally, they’re well settled and well freed when it comes to both agreeable and disagreeable sights,

sn46.6:5.6.pli: manasā dhammaṃ viññāya manāpāmanāpesu dhammesu ṭhito ca kāyo hoti, ṭhitaṃ cittaṃ ajjhattaṃ susaṇṭhitaṃ suvimuttaṃ.

sn46.6:5.7.pli: Evaṃ bhāvito kho, kuṇḍaliya, indriyasaṃvaro evaṃ bahulīkato tīṇi sucaritāni paripūreti.
sn46.6:5.7.eng: That’s how sense restraint is developed and cultivated so as to fulfill the three kinds of good conduct.

sn46.6:6.1.pli: Kathaṃ bhāvitāni ca, kuṇḍaliya, tīṇi sucaritāni kathaṃ bahulīkatāni cattāro satipaṭṭhāne paripūrenti?
sn46.6:6.1.eng: And how are the three kinds of good conduct developed and cultivated so as to fulfill the four kinds of mindfulness meditation?

sn46.6:6.2.pli: Idha, kuṇḍaliya, bhikkhu kāyaduccaritaṃ pahāya kāyasucaritaṃ bhāveti, vacīduccaritaṃ pahāya vacīsucaritaṃ bhāveti, manoduccaritaṃ pahāya manosucaritaṃ bhāveti.
sn46.6:6.2.eng: A mendicant gives up bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and develops good conduct by way of body, speech, and mind.

sn46.6:6.3.pli: Evaṃ bhāvitāni kho, kuṇḍaliya, tīṇi sucaritāni evaṃ bahulīkatāni cattāro satipaṭṭhāne paripūrenti.
sn46.6:6.3.eng: That’s how the three kinds of good conduct are developed and cultivated so as to fulfill the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

sn46.6:7.1.pli: Kathaṃ bhāvitā ca, kuṇḍaliya, cattāro satipaṭṭhānā kathaṃ bahulīkatā satta bojjhaṅge paripūrenti?
sn46.6:7.1.eng: And how are the four kinds of mindfulness meditation developed and cultivated so as to fulfill the seven awakening factors?

sn46.6:7.2.pli: Idha, kuṇḍaliya, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn46.6:7.2.eng: A mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn46.6:7.3.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …

sn46.6:7.5.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn46.6:7.5.eng: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn46.6:7.6.pli: Evaṃ bhāvitā kho, kuṇḍaliya, cattāro satipaṭṭhānā evaṃ bahulīkatā satta bojjhaṅge paripūrenti.
sn46.6:7.6.eng: That’s how the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are developed and cultivated so as to fulfill the seven awakening factors.

sn46.6:8.1.pli: Kathaṃ bhāvitā ca, kuṇḍaliya, satta bojjhaṅgā kathaṃ bahulīkatā vijjāvimuttiṃ paripūrenti?
sn46.6:8.1.eng: And how are the seven awakening factors developed and cultivated so as to fulfill knowledge and freedom?

sn46.6:8.2.pli: Idha, kuṇḍaliya, bhikkhu satisambojjhaṅgaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ …pe…
sn46.6:8.2.eng: A mendicant develops the awakening factors of mindfulness, investigation of principles, energy, rapture, tranquility, immersion,

sn46.6:8.3.pli: upekkhāsambojjhaṅgaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ.
sn46.6:8.3.eng: and equanimity, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.

sn46.6:8.4.pli: Evaṃ bhāvitā kho, kuṇḍaliya, satta bojjhaṅgā evaṃ bahulīkatā vijjāvimuttiṃ paripūrentī”ti.
sn46.6:8.4.eng: That’s how the seven awakening factors are developed and cultivated so as to fulfill knowledge and freedom.”

sn46.6:9.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, kuṇḍaliyo paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn46.6:9.1.eng: When he said this, the wanderer Kuṇḍaliya said to the Buddha,

sn46.6:9.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evameva bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
sn46.6:9.3.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.

sn46.6:9.4.pli: Esāhaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
sn46.6:9.4.eng: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

sn46.6:9.5.pli: Upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
sn46.6:9.5.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

sn46.60:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when the perception of a split open corpse is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial. …”

sn46.61:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when the perception of a bloated corpse is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial. …”

sn46.62:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when love is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial. …”

sn46.63:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when compassion is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial. …”

sn46.64:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when rejoicing is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial. …”

sn46.65:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when equanimity is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial. …”

sn46.66:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial. …”

sn46.67:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when the perception of ugliness is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial. …”

sn46.68:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when the perception of death is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial. …”

sn46.69:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when the perception of repulsiveness of food is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial. …”

sn46.7:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, kūṭāgārassa yā kāci gopānasiyo, sabbā tā kūṭaninnā kūṭapoṇā kūṭapabbhārā;
sn46.7:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, the rafters of a bungalow all slant, slope, and incline to the peak.

sn46.7:1.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu satta bojjhaṅge bhāvento satta bojjhaṅge bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro.
sn46.7:1.2.eng: In the same way, a mendicant who develops and cultivates the seven awakening factors slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.

sn46.7:2.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu satta bojjhaṅge bhāvento satta bojjhaṅge bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro?
sn46.7:2.1.eng: And how does a mendicant who develops the seven awakening factors slant, slope, and incline to extinguishment?

sn46.7:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu satisambojjhaṅgaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ …pe…
sn46.7:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops the awakening factors of mindfulness, investigation of principles, energy, rapture, tranquility, immersion,

sn46.7:2.3.pli: upekkhāsambojjhaṅgaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ.
sn46.7:2.3.eng: and equanimity, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.

sn46.7:2.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu satta bojjhaṅge bhāvento satta bojjhaṅge bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro”ti.
sn46.7:2.4.eng: That’s how a mendicant who develops and cultivates the seven awakening factors slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.”

sn46.70:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when the perception of dissatisfaction with the whole world is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial. …”

sn46.71:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when the perception of impermanence is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial. …”

sn46.72:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when the perception of suffering in impermanence is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial. …”

sn46.73:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when the perception of not-self in suffering is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial. …”

sn46.74:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when the perception of giving up is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial. …”

sn46.75:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when the perception of dispassion is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial. …”

sn46.76:1.1.pli: “Nirodhasaññā, bhikkhave, bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā hoti mahānisaṃsā.
sn46.76:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, when the perception of cessation is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial.

sn46.76:1.2.pli: Kathaṃ bhāvitā ca, bhikkhave, nirodhasaññā kathaṃ bahulīkatā mahapphalā hoti mahānisaṃsā?

sn46.76:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu nirodhasaññāsahagataṃ satisambojjhaṅgaṃ bhāveti …pe…
sn46.76:1.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops the perception of cessation together with the awakening factors of mindfulness, investigation of principles, energy, rapture, tranquility, immersion,

sn46.76:1.4.pli: nirodhasaññāsahagataṃ upekkhāsambojjhaṅgaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ.
sn46.76:1.4.eng: and equanimity, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.

sn46.76:1.5.pli: Evaṃ bhāvitā kho, bhikkhave, nirodhasaññā evaṃ bahulīkatā mahapphalā hoti mahānisaṃsāti.
sn46.76:1.5.eng: That’s how, when the perception of cessation is developed and cultivated, it’s very fruitful and beneficial.

sn46.76:2.1.pli: Nirodhasaññāya, bhikkhave, bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya dvinnaṃ phalānaṃ aññataraṃ phalaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—
sn46.76:2.1.eng: When the perception of cessation is developed and cultivated you can expect one of two results:

sn46.76:2.2.pli: diṭṭheva dhamme aññā, sati vā upādisese anāgāmitā.
sn46.76:2.2.eng: enlightenment in this very life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.

sn46.76:2.3.pli: Kathaṃ bhāvitāya, bhikkhave, nirodhasaññāya kathaṃ bahulīkatāya dvinnaṃ phalānaṃ aññataraṃ phalaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—

sn46.76:2.4.pli: diṭṭheva dhamme aññā, sati vā upādisese anāgāmitā?

sn46.76:2.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu nirodhasaññāsahagataṃ satisambojjhaṅgaṃ bhāveti …pe…
sn46.76:2.5.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops the perception of cessation together with the awakening factors of mindfulness, investigation of principles, energy, rapture, tranquility, immersion,

sn46.76:2.6.pli: nirodhasaññāsahagataṃ upekkhāsambojjhaṅgaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ.
sn46.76:2.6.eng: and equanimity, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.

sn46.76:2.7.pli: Evaṃ bhāvitāya kho, bhikkhave, nirodhasaññāya evaṃ bahulīkatāya dvinnaṃ phalānaṃ aññataraṃ phalaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—
sn46.76:2.7.eng: When the perception of cessation is developed and cultivated in this way you can expect one of two results:

sn46.76:2.8.pli: diṭṭheva dhamme aññā, sati vā upādisese anāgāmitāti.
sn46.76:2.8.eng: enlightenment in this very life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.”

sn46.76:3.1.pli: Nirodhasaññā, bhikkhave, bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahato atthāya saṃvattati, mahato yogakkhemāya saṃvattati, mahato saṃvegāya saṃvattati, mahato phāsuvihārāya saṃvattati.
sn46.76:3.1.eng: “The perception of cessation, when developed and cultivated, leads to great benefit … great sanctuary from the yoke … great inspiration … great ease.

sn46.76:3.2.pli: Kathaṃ bhāvitā ca, bhikkhave, nirodhasaññā kathaṃ bahulīkatā mahato atthāya saṃvattati, mahato yogakkhemāya saṃvattati, mahato saṃvegāya saṃvattati, mahato phāsuvihārāya saṃvattati?

sn46.76:3.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu nirodhasaññāsahagataṃ satisambojjhaṅgaṃ bhāveti …pe…
sn46.76:3.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops the perception of cessation together with the awakening factors of mindfulness, investigation of principles, energy, rapture, tranquility, immersion,

sn46.76:3.4.pli: nirodhasaññāsahagataṃ upekkhāsambojjhaṅgaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ.
sn46.76:3.4.eng: and equanimity, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.

sn46.76:3.5.pli: Evaṃ bhāvitā kho, bhikkhave, nirodhasaññā evaṃ bahulīkatā mahato atthāya saṃvattati, mahato yogakkhemāya saṃvattati, mahato saṃvegāya saṃvattati, mahato phāsuvihārāya saṃvattatī”ti.
sn46.76:3.5.eng: That’s how the perception of cessation, when developed and cultivated, leads to great benefit … great sanctuary from the yoke … great inspiration … great ease.”

sn46.77-88:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, gaṅgā nadī pācīnaninnā pācīnapoṇā pācīnapabbhārā;
sn46.77-88:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, the Ganges river slants, slopes, and inclines to the east.

sn46.77-88:1.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu satta bojjhaṅge bhāvento satta bojjhaṅge bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro.
sn46.77-88:1.2.eng: In the same way, a mendicant who develops and cultivates the seven awakening factors slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.

sn46.77-88:1.3.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu satta bojjhaṅge bhāvento satta bojjhaṅge bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro?
sn46.77-88:1.3.eng: And how does a mendicant who develops the seven awakening factors slant, slope, and incline to extinguishment?

sn46.77-88:1.4.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops the awakening factors of mindfulness, investigation of principles, energy, rapture, tranquility, immersion,

sn46.77-88:1.5.pli: upekkhāsambojjhaṅgaṃ bhāveti vivekanissitaṃ virāganissitaṃ nirodhanissitaṃ vossaggapariṇāmiṃ …
sn46.77-88:1.5.eng: and equanimity, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.

sn46.77-88:1.6.pli: evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu satta bojjhaṅge bhāvento satta bojjhaṅge bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro”ti.
sn46.77-88:1.6.eng: That’s how a mendicant who develops and cultivates the seven awakening factors slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.”

sn46.77-88:1.7.eng: (Tell in full for each of the different rivers as in SN 45.91–102.)

sn46.8:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā ca upavāno āyasmā ca sāriputto kosambiyaṃ viharanti ghositārāme.
sn46.8:1.1.eng: At one time the venerables Upavāṇa and Sāriputta were staying near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery.

sn46.8:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yenāyasmā upavāno tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā upavānena saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn46.8:1.2.eng: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Sāriputta came out of retreat, went to Venerable Upavāṇa and exchanged greetings with him.

sn46.8:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā sāriputto āyasmantaṃ upavānaṃ etadavoca:
sn46.8:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to Upavāṇa:

sn46.8:2.1.pli: “Jāneyya nu kho, āvuso upavāna, bhikkhu ‘paccattaṃ yonisomanasikārā evaṃ susamāraddhā me satta bojjhaṅgā phāsuvihārāya saṃvattantī’”ti?
sn46.8:2.1.eng: “Reverend Upavāṇa, can a mendicant know by investigating inside themselves that the seven awakening factors are properly implemented so that they lead to living at ease?”

sn46.8:2.2.pli: “Jāneyya kho, āvuso sāriputta, bhikkhu ‘paccattaṃ yonisomanasikārā evaṃ susamāraddhā me satta bojjhaṅgā phāsuvihārāya saṃvattantī’”ti.

sn46.8:3.1.pli: “Satisambojjhaṅgaṃ kho, āvuso, bhikkhu ārabbhamāno pajānāti ‘cittañca me suvimuttaṃ, thinamiddhañca me susamūhataṃ, uddhaccakukkuccañca me suppaṭivinītaṃ, āraddhañca me vīriyaṃ, aṭṭhiṃ katvā manasi karomi, no ca līnan’ti …pe…
sn46.8:3.1.eng: As a mendicant rouses up the awakening factor of mindfulness, they understand: ‘My mind is well freed. I’ve eradicated dullness and drowsiness, and eliminated restlessness and remorse. My energy is roused up, and my mind is sharply focused, not sluggish.’ …

sn46.8:3.2.pli: upekkhāsambojjhaṅgaṃ āvuso, bhikkhu ārabbhamāno pajānāti ‘cittañca me suvimuttaṃ, thinamiddhañca me susamūhataṃ, uddhaccakukkuccañca me suppaṭivinītaṃ, āraddhañca me vīriyaṃ, aṭṭhiṃ katvā manasi karomi, no ca līnan’”ti.
sn46.8:3.2.eng: As they rouse up the awakening factor of equanimity, they understand: ‘My mind is well freed. I’ve eradicated dullness and drowsiness, and eliminated restlessness and remorse. My energy is roused up, and my mind is sharply focused, not sluggish.’

sn46.8:3.3.pli: “Evaṃ kho, āvuso sāriputta, bhikkhu jāneyya ‘paccattaṃ yonisomanasikārā evaṃ susamāraddhā me satta bojjhaṅgā phāsuvihārāya saṃvattantī’”ti.
sn46.8:3.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant can know by investigating inside themselves that the seven awakening factors are properly implemented so that they lead to living at ease.”

sn46.89-98:1.1.pli: “Yāvatā, bhikkhave, sattā apadā vā dvipadā vā catuppadā vā bahuppadā vā”ti vitthāretabbaṃ.
sn46.89-98:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, is said to be the best of all sentient beings—be they footless, with two feet, four feet, or many feet …”

sn46.9:1.1.pli: “Sattime, bhikkhave, bojjhaṅgā bhāvitā bahulīkatā anuppannā uppajjanti, nāññatra tathāgatassa pātubhāvā arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
sn46.9:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these seven awakening factors don’t arise to be developed and cultivated except when a Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha has appeared.

sn46.9:1.3.eng: The awakening factors of mindfulness, investigation of principles, energy, rapture, tranquility, immersion, and equanimity.

sn46.9:1.4.pli: ime kho, bhikkhave, satta bojjhaṅgā bhāvitā bahulīkatā anuppannā uppajjanti, nāññatra tathāgatassa pātubhāvā arahato sammāsambuddhassā”ti.
sn46.9:1.4.eng: These seven awakening factors don’t arise to be developed and cultivated except when a Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha has appeared.”

sn46.99-110:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ye keci balakaraṇīyā kammantā karīyan”ti vitthāretabbaṃ.
sn46.99-110:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, all the hard work that gets done depends on the earth and is grounded on the earth. …”

sn47.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati ambapālivane.
sn47.1:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, in Ambapālī’s Mango Grove.

sn47.1:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

sn47.1:2.1.pli: “Ekāyanvāyaṃ, bhikkhave, maggo sattānaṃ visuddhiyā sokaparidevānaṃ samatikkamāya dukkhadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamāya ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya, yadidaṃ—cattāro satipaṭṭhānā.
sn47.1:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the path to convergence. They are in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to discover the system, and to realize extinguishment.

sn47.1:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.1:2.3.eng: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.1:2.4.pli: vedanāsu vedanānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.1:2.4.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.1:2.5.pli: citte cittānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
sn47.1:2.5.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.1:2.6.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
sn47.1:2.6.eng: They meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.

sn47.1:2.7.pli: Ekāyanvāyaṃ, bhikkhave, maggo sattānaṃ visuddhiyā sokaparidevānaṃ samatikkamāya dukkhadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamāya ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya, yadidaṃ—cattāro satipaṭṭhānā”ti.
sn47.1:2.7.eng: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the path to convergence. They are in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to discover the system, and to realize extinguishment.”

sn47.1:3.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn47.1:3.2.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
sn47.1:3.2.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
